title: OE(thel)
content:
i want to make an [Ethel](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021130139/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Ethel) like the one I’ve attached. I know i’ve seen this form somewhere before... can anyone help me out?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [ethel.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021130139/http:/typophile.com/files/ethel.gif) | 4.33 KB |

 [‹ DIstressing Type](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021130139/http:/typophile.com/node/15102 "Go to previous forum topic") [Current Swiss Design ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021130139/http:/typophile.com/node/15031 "Go to next forum topic")
author: paul d hunt

comments.content: According to the [the Unicode folks](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021130139/http:/www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/16df/index.htm), an Ethel (or _œðel_) is a Runic character, but it doesn’t much resemble your example.
and i thought Bringhurst was the authority on _everything_! In any case, I’m referring here to the OE ligature.

I’ve not seen the O and E overlapped so much before. It seems like it would be a dark spot in the text and stick out though.

ChrisL

I’ve seen that form before too. I’m thinking Koch, or maybe a Czech.

hhp

It’s an archaic form. I’ve seen it used in a title page from the Imprimerie Royale, 1750, spelling “OEUVRES”, where it is useful to avoid three consecutive vowels.  
Transitional.
nick! are you back on the continent yet?

Oh yes, I think I might have recently seen it in some IN book [too].  
Paul, let me know if you’d like me to track it down.

BTW, I’m curious: What’s wrong with three vowels (visually)? Also, the “OE” there is linked due to grammatical rules - it’s like a distinct letter, so it’s not like it’s an option (although Baskerville for one has set them -or actually an “AE”- as two characters, just using tighter spacing to “link” them).

hhp

_... it is useful to avoid three consecutive vowels_

There’s an Aegean island in _The Odyssey_ call Aeaea, sometimes spelled Aiaia. How’s that for vowels?

\> Aeaea

Ah yes, home of the mythical Greek Tarzan!

OK, some vowel trivia:  
What’s the only word in Arabic that’s made up only of vowels?

hhp
